text: Cancer has already been cured but Big Pharma buried it. Think about how much money they’d lose. 💰🧪
explanation: A common conspiracy theory. No evidence supports the idea that a cure is being hidden.

text: If you crack your knuckles, you’ll get arthritis. Grandma was right. 👵🖐️
explanation: False. Studies show no link between knuckle cracking and arthritis.

text: Vaccines give you the disease they're supposed to prevent. It’s in the ingredients list. 💉😡
explanation: False. Vaccines use weakened or inactive forms (or fragments) of pathogens and don’t cause the disease.

text: Fluoride in toothpaste lowers your IQ. That’s why it’s in the water too. 🧠🦷
explanation: No credible studies support this claim. Fluoride prevents tooth decay and is safe at regulated levels.

text: Drinking water with lemon cures cancer. Oncologists won’t tell you this. 🍋🚱
explanation: No scientific evidence supports this claim. Lemon water is healthy but not a cancer treatment.

text: You *can* overdose on vitamins. Just because it’s 'natural' doesn’t mean it’s safe. 🍊🚫
explanation: Correct. Some vitamins (like A or D) can be toxic in high doses.

text: Garlic doesn’t cure cancer, but it *does* have legit antimicrobial properties. Nature isn't useless. 🧄💊
explanation: True. Garlic has documented antimicrobial and anti-inflammatory effects, though it's no miracle cure.

text: Doctors used to recommend smoking for stress. Like, in real ads. 😬🚬
explanation: True. In the early 20th century, some doctors endorsed cigarettes in advertising.

text: Walking is one of the most underrated things you can do for your health. Not sexy, just facts. 🚶‍♂️❤️
explanation: True. Regular walking improves cardiovascular health, reduces stress, and increases longevity.

text: Most cold meds don’t cure anything—they just make you feel less miserable while your body does the work. 🤧🕒
explanation: Yes. Cold medications typically treat symptoms, not the virus itself.
